meanings.def: to make food, drink, etc. go down your throat into your stomach
examples: swallow (something) Always chew food well before swallowing it.
I had a sore throat and it hurt to swallow.
swallow something + adj. The pills should be swallowed whole.
Liquid food may be more easily swallowed.
Most snakes swallow their prey whole.
She accidentally swallowed a glass bead.
She swallowed down her breakfast in a hurry.

meanings.def: to move the muscles of your throat as if you were swallowing something, especially because you are nervous
examples: She swallowed hard and told him the bad news.
He swallowed back the lump in his throat.
She swallowed convulsively, determined not to cry.

meanings.def: to take somebody/something in or completely cover them/it so that they/it cannot be seen or exist separately any longer
examples: swallow somebody/something I watched her walk down the road until she was swallowed by the darkness.
swallow somebody/something up Large areas of countryside have been swallowed up by towns.

meanings.def: to use up something completely, especially an amount of money
examples: Most of my salary gets swallowed (up) by the rent and bills.

meanings.def: to accept that something is true; to believe something
examples: swallow something I found her excuse very hard to swallow.
swallow something + adj. He told her a pack of lies, but she swallowed it whole.
to swallow your doubts
You're going to have to swallow your pride and ask for your job back.

meanings.def: to accept offensive remarks, criticisms, etc. without complaining or protesting
examples: I was surprised that he just sat there and swallowed all their remarks.

meanings.def: a fact or an event that is unpleasant and difficult to accept
examples: The election defeat was a bitter pill for the party to swallow.
She looked like a cat that’s swallowed the canary. She was almost purring with pleasure.

idioms.def: a fact or an event that is unpleasant and difficult to accept
examples: The election defeat was a bitter pill for the party to swallow.

idioms.idiom: like the cat that got/ate/swallowed the canary
examples: She looked like a cat that’s swallowed the canary. She was almost purring with pleasure.

related: one swallow doesn’t make a summer

meanings.def: a small bird, with long pointed wings and a tail with two points, that migrates (= moves from one part of the world to another according to the season)
an act of swallowing; an amount of food or drink that is swallowed at one time
examples: She took a swallow of coffee.

meanings.def: you must not take too seriously a small sign that something is happening or will happen in the future, because the situation could change
